quality_assessment.notes: High natural acidity, precision, and purity of fruit with characteristic minerality. Some bottle-aged examples show complex petrol and honeyed notes.
Intense ripe fruit balanced by vibrant acidity. Stone and honey notes develop with age, giving complexity while maintaining freshness.
Structured with firm tannins and concentrated black fruit. Oak adds complexity, while age brings tobacco, cedar, and earthy tones typical of quality Bordeaux Cabernet Sauvignon.

Supple, plush fruit profile with polished tannins and rich secondary notes from oak. With age, complex earthy, truffle, and tobacco tones emerge—typical of top Right Bank Merlot (e.g., Saint-Émilion or Pomerol).
Fresh, vibrant red fruit with lively acidity and gentle tannins. Almond and herbal notes are characteristic; tertiary notes deepen in more serious expressions or with age.
Rich, concentrated, and powerful with intense dried-fruit character, high alcohol, and complex oak and tertiary notes. Amarone shows depth, harmony, and exceptional ageing potential.
Shows added depth and richness from the Ripasso method, with dried-fruit notes and gentle spice while retaining freshness and drinkability. A bridge between Valpolicella Classico and Amarone.
Fresh, juicy red fruit with lively acidity and low tannin. Floral and carbonic notes common; top crus show additional depth, spice, and subtle earthiness.

other_observations: slight garnet rim with bottle age

quality_assessment.notes: More depth, complexity, and structure than basic Beaujolais. Darker fruit, mineral notes, and subtle spice show terroir expression. Some Crus age well, developing earthy, savoury complexity.

palate.sweetness: off-dry (can be dry to medium-sweet depending on producer)

quality_assessment.notes: Highly aromatic, opulent, and exotic with intense floral and stone-fruit character. Lower acidity but rich texture; complex spicy and honeyed notes with age.
Rich, ripe dark fruit with plush tannins and high alcohol. Oak adds spice and chocolate notes; top regions like Uco Valley bring floral aromas and fresher acidity.
More structured and tannic than Argentinian Malbec, with darker fruit, pronounced earthiness, and savory complexity. Excellent ageing potential, especially from top terroirs ('Causses').
Aromatic, complex, and highly structured with firm tannins and bright acidity. Floral and red-fruit core supported by tar, spice, and earthy tertiaries. Exceptional ageing potential.
Typically well-balanced with bright acidity and delicate fruit; some examples show complexity from oak and development.

readiness_for_drinking.notes: Good Bourgogne-level Pinot Noir is enjoyable young but can develop earthy notes with a few years of bottle age.

quality_assessment.notes: Bright acidity and firm tannins define Sangiovese. Red-cherry purity with herbal and balsamic notes; develops earthy, leathery complexity with age. Excellent food wine and highly expressive of terroir.
Complex, spice-driven, and savoury with intense dark fruit, pepper, and meaty notes. Structured but elegant; top examples age beautifully with gamey and earthy tertiary development.

other_observations: viscous tears, typical of higher alcohol and low acidity

quality_assessment.notes: Aromatic, lush, and expressive with ripe stone fruit, floral perfume, and rich texture. Low acidity balanced by concentration and aromatic intensity. Condrieu examples can be profound and age gracefully.

other_observations: light pétillance in some young wines

quality_assessment.notes: Bright, refreshing, and aromatic with zesty citrus, stone fruit, and a distinct saline-mineral character from coastal vineyards. Crisp acidity and purity make it highly food-friendly.
Bright acidity defines Barbera. Juicy red and black cherry fruit with moderate tannins, plus spice and oak depending on winemaking. More structured wines from Asti can show depth and age gracefully.

Elegant, balanced, and expressive with vibrant acidity and layers of citrus, stone fruit, and mineral notes. Oak influence ranges from subtle to pronounced in Côte de Beaune styles, adding depth and complexity.

other_observations: lighter rim due to low anthocyanins

quality_assessment.notes: Warm, ripe red fruit with characteristic garrigue herbs and spice. High alcohol balanced by richness and depth. Top expressions (e.g., Châteauneuf-du-Pape) show complexity, texture, and excellent ageing potential.

Tempranillo combines ripe red fruit with distinctive oak notes (especially American oak) and develops savoury leather, earth, and tobacco complexity with age. Ribera del Duero styles are darker and more powerful; Rioja can be more elegant and aromatic.

Bold, ripe, and expressive with jammy dark fruit, high alcohol, and spice. Oak contributes vanilla and cocoa, while ageing brings dried-fruit complexity. Distinctive, powerful, and deeply Californian in style.
Lean, high-acid, mineral-driven Sauvignon Blanc with classic Loire green aromatics and flinty precision.
Extremely aromatic and distinctive; tropical fruit, citrus, and green vegetal notes are unmistakable.
Austere and precise with piercing acidity and signature lime/petrol character.
Classic orchard fruit, high acidity, and lanolin notes; capable of ageing superbly.
Peppery, herbal, high-acid white with strong terroir expression and versatility.
Rich, opulent, oak-driven Cabernet with ripe dark fruit, plush tannins, and high alcohol.
Ripe, powerful, and distinctive with eucalyptus, chocolate, and intense dark fruit.
Fresh, herbal, and peppery with red fruit and graphite; classic Loire profile.
Deeply structured, savoury, and powerful with game, herbs, and dark fruit. A benchmark blind-tasting profile.
Ripe, rich, and oaked with tropical fruit and creamy MLF notes; classic Californian style.
Modern style with bright citrus, minerality, and subtle oak; often reductive/smoky.
Sweet red fruit, spice, and soft tannins typical of West Coast Pinot; richer than Burgundy.
Highly aromatic with floral and citrus notes; easily confused with Gewürztraminer but always drier/crisper.
Citrus-herbal white with a distinctive bitter almond finish; often mistaken for Loire Sauvignon Blanc.
Distinctive smoky and coffee notes with dark fruit; unmistakable blind tasting signature.

other_observations: very light color even with age

quality_assessment.notes: Iconic Hunter style: low alcohol, high acidity, and dramatic ageing into toast and honey.
Dense, tannic, deeply colored wine with black fruit and heavy structure; often a blind tasting trap.
Distinctive green peppercorn and herbal character with dark fruit; a key Chilean signature.
Highly pale and delicate with fresh red fruit and light earthy notes. A unique Jura signature that is easily recognizable in blind tastings.
High-acid, mineral-driven, slightly nutty white with a distinct Jura almond note. Ouillé style is precise and linear; can evolve into complex nutty, honeyed expressions.
